qas.question: In 1997 who revised the classification of mammals?

answers.text: Malcolm C. McKenna and Susan K. Bell

qas.question: Where did the two authors work together as paleontologist?
From whom did McKenna inherit the project from?
Who did Simpson inherit the project from?
What happened to molecular genetic data in 1997?

plausible_answers.text: Classification of Mammals above the Species Level

qas.question: What was the book written by Simpson?

plausible_answers.text: the systematics, relationships, and occurrences of all mammal taxa, living and extinct

qas.question: What information about mammals does Simpson's book cover?
What did Simpson help construct with Bell?

context: In 1997, the mammals were <b4_0>comprehensively revised<b4_0/> by <a0_0>Malcolm C. McKenna and Susan K. Bell<a0_0/>, which has resulted in the McKenna/Bell classification. Their 1997 book, <b5_0>Classification of Mammals above the Species Level<b5_0/>, is the most comprehensive work to date on <b6_0>the systematics, relationships, and occurrences of all mammal taxa, living and extinct<b6_0/>, down through the rank of genus, though recent molecular genetic data challenge several of the higher level groupings. The authors worked together as paleontologists at the <a1_0>American Museum of Natural History<a1_0/>, New York. <b3_0>McKenna<b3_0/> inherited the project from <a2_0>Simpson<a2_0/> and, with Bell, constructed <b7_0>a completely updated hierarchical system<b7_0/>, covering living and extinct taxa that reflects the historical genealogy of Mammalia.
